DataElementConcept.preferredName: Chimerism Laboratory Procedure Evaluation Method Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual._Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting._A description of the technique for the appraisal of a subject or object._Executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.:A medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood, urine, or other substance from the body. Tests can help determine a diagnosis, plan treatment, check to see if treatment is working, or monitor the disease over time.

Concepts.definition: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredDefinition: A description of the technique for the appraisal of a subject or object.:Performed; carried out.

Concepts.definition: A description of the technique for the appraisal of a subject or object.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the type of evaluation or test used to determine chimerism.

PermissibleValues.value: Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) for XX/XY
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: XX Genotype And/Or XY Genotype Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization

ValueMeaning.preferredName: XX Genotype And/Or XY Genotype Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The normal genotype of a female human.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: The normal genotype of a male human.: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.

Concepts.definition: The normal genotype of a female human.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
The normal genotype of a male human.

A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of IN SITU HYBRIDIZATION in which target sequences are stained with fluorescent dye so their location and size can be determined using fluorescence microscopy. This staining is sufficiently distinct that the hybridization signal can be seen both in metaphase spreads and in interphase nuclei.

Concepts.definition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: the study of genetics at the chromosomal level.

Concepts.definition: The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

PermissibleValues.value: VNTR or STR, micro or mini satellite

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tandem arrays of moderately repetitive (5-50 repeats) short (10-60 bases) DNA sequences found dispersed throughout the genome and clustered near telomeres.  Their degree of repetition is two to several hundred at each locus.  Loci number in the thousands but each locus shows a distinctive repeat unit.  Minisatellite repeats are often called variable number of tandem repeats.

Concepts.definition: Tandem arrays of moderately repetitive (5-50 repeats) short (10-60 bases) DNA sequences found dispersed throughout the genome and clustered near telomeres.  Their degree of repetition is two to several hundred at each locus.  Loci number in the thousands but each locus shows a distinctive repeat unit.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The human leukocyte antigen (HLA) test, also known as HLA typing or tissue typing, identifies antigens on the white blood cells (WBCs) that determine tissue compatibility for organ transplantation (that is, histocompatibility testing). There are six loci on chromosome 6, where the genes that produce HLA antigens are inherited: HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, HLA-DR, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DP
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Variation occurring within a species in the length of DNA fragments generated by a specific endonuclease. Such variations are generated by mutations that create or abolish recognition sites for these enzymes.

Concepts.definition: Variation occurring within a species in the length of DNA fragments generated by a specific endonuclease. Such variations are generated by mutations that create or abolish recognition sites for these enzymes.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: XX Genotype And/Or XY Genotype Karyotyping

ValueMeaning.preferredName: XX Genotype And/Or XY Genotype Karyotyping
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The normal genotype of a female human.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: The normal genotype of a male human.: The preparation, analysis, and interpretation of a karyotype, the representation of the chromosome set of a cell.

Concepts.definition: The normal genotype of a female human.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
The normal genotype of a male human.
The preparation, analysis, and interpretation of a karyotype, the representation of the chromosome set of a cell.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.

Concepts.definition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 7-20-20 TMT updated concept with NCIt definition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.

Concepts.definition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

Concepts.definition: The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.
